ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed my critical thinking skills and mathematical intuition.
I further developed my understanding of the basic concepts of calculus.
I learned how to do single variable calculus, simple integration, and think about questions critically incorporating concepts and theories from a span of mathematical disciplines.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Pros: Good teaching and able to ask questions, plentiful office hours, nicely structured.

Cons: some PSET's seemed overly challenging given material that had been completed in class.

Strength: I had a great instructor.

Weakness: This course moves too quickly, and I would appreciate more course material (e.g. notes) to aid our learning. Also, from talking to my peers, I learned that teaching quality varies a lot between instructors.
Make PSets more similar to what is asked on exams. The only real preparation for exams are the past exams. PSets are really different from what we are tested on.

Strengths: Professor Yarmola, his handouts, peer tutors
Weaknesses: peer tutor hours are 9pm onwards, there is no streamline in the handouts per section, choosing a section Professor with low ratings will directly reflect on your grades, very time consuming
A strength of this course was having the Ximera practice sections. A weakness was the lack of adequate preparation for how much work should be shown on exams.

I think advising and tutoring resources for this course could be better organized as it was very difficult to find more tutoring that worked well for me as a student who was struggling with the content and generally benefits from more personalized tutoring than was made available to me this semester through the TAs. If you have a need for slower, more one-on-one help, which I very much needed this term, it is entirely up to the willingness and availability of your professor whether you can get it or not. I was fortunate enough to have a professor that made himself very available to us and whose teaching style worked really well as he was able to find new ways to explain concepts at a pace that worked for me. Not everyone was access to this availability and synergy with their professor, so I think there should be more options for receiving one-on-one tutoring throughout the semester both for psets and going over class material, which we learn at a very fast pace.

Strengths: the ximeras and psets ensured that we did not fall behind in the material and aided the learning done in class.

Weaknesses: the class was very fast paced and falling behind in one session was very risky.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you would like a standard calc class or need it for a major.
Yes, but only if they need it to fulfill a prerequisite for their desired major. I would not recommend it to someone hoping to fall in love with mathematics.
Wouldn't take it for fun, of course. The course does its job as a prerequisite. Good course.
Only take it if you have to
I would only if it were a prerequisite, though I would not recommend it if not necessary, due to the lack of support in learning new concepts.
I would, I think the material and skills covered in this course are important for a variety of disciplines.
